page.title: 08LOCAL HOUSING
page.content: The majority of this area is sparsely developed being agricultural land dotted with farms and cottages dating from 15th, 16th and 17th century. Generally these are of timber frame construction (oak) with lath and plaster or, in later examples, brick and flint infill. Roofing is generally of clay peg tile or long straw thatch. Little Lodge and Great Lodge are important brick built manor houses. There are 19th and 2Oth century houses scattered throughout the area, predominantly on the fringes of Shalford and Great Bardfield. The new building particularly in the late 4O's and 6O's was of conventional cavity construction of brick and concrete blocks under cement tiled roof. Planning constriction in the last 15 years has severly restricted housing development in this rural area.
